habits.name: Personal Time-Blocking
habits.description: Implement time-blocking in my personal work to increase focus and completion of tasks, especially music production

atomicPrinciples.habitStack: after I sit down at my workspace, I will spend 2 minutes reviewing my time-blocked schedule
implementationIntentions: when I feel scattered or unfocused, I will return to my time-blocked schedule
before starting a creative session with my MPC, I will block time for that specific creative work
after completing a client session, I will block transition time before moving to the next activity
atomicPrinciples.identityConnection: I am the type of person who structures my time intentionally, which helps me complete creative projects and serve clients effectively

habits.cue: when I sit down at my workspace
habits.craving: to have clarity and direction for my work session
habits.response: review and confirm my time-blocked schedule for the next 90 minutes
habits.reward: feeling organized and focused about what to work on
environmentChanges: have digital calendar visible at workspace
set up notification-free zones during focused work
designate specific areas for different types of work

playfulElements: Use colorful calendar blocks like building blocks
Turn schedule conflicts into "puzzle solving" challenges
Celebrate time-block completions with small rewards
Make transitions between blocks into "scene changes"
cognitiveRestructuring: Time-blocking gives me freedom by reducing decision fatigue
Scheduling time for creative work increases rather than restricts creativity
Time boundaries protect my energy for important work
Structured time allows for more spontaneous creative moments
behavioralExperiments: Test: Blocking time for creative work increases rather than decreases creative output
Experiment: See if having scheduled breaks increases overall productivity
Try: Blocking time for the same activity at different times of day to see which works better
Test: How much time blocking is too much vs. too little
gamification: Level up time-blocking skills by increasing complexity gradually
Unlock new time-blocking techniques as I master basics
Quest system for integrating time-blocking with different activities
creativeExpression: Draw or sketch my weekly schedule
Use colors and visual elements to represent different activities
Create a visual timeline of my day
Design custom icons for different types of activities
emotionalProcessing: Connect time-blocking to feeling more in control of my life
Link structured time to reduced anxiety about forgotten tasks
Associate time-blocking with increased creative output
Connect scheduling to feeling more spacious in my days

metacognitiveAwareness: Monitor my awareness of time throughout the day
Reflect on how well my time-blocking aligns with my energy levels
Evaluate effectiveness of different time-blocking approaches
Notice when I deviate from time-blocks and why
cognitiveLoadManagement: Keep time-blocking simple to reduce decision fatigue
Use visual aids to reduce memory load
Batch similar activities to reduce switching costs
Limit the number of time-blocks to prevent overload
attentionBiasModification: Notice when mind wanders from planned tasks
Use cues to redirect attention when distracted
cognitiveFlexibility: Modify schedule when it's not working
schemaModification: Challenge belief that structure restricts creativity
Reframe time-blocking as freedom from decision fatigue
Modify belief that I can multitask effectively
Update beliefs about how much time tasks take
executiveFunctionSupport: Use planning skills to organize time-blocks
Apply inhibitory control to resist distractions
Use working memory to hold time-blocking intentions

settings.defaultIdentityFocus: Who is the person I want to become?
